 Marriage is not mentioned in the Constitution, but the states are free to enact marriage laws (and have done so). The Constitutional question isn't whether there should be marriage or shouldn't be -- the states have decided there should be. One Constitutional guarantee is that a marriage in one state is valid in another (with very few restrictions). The Constitutional question today is whether the states are allowed to discriminate in applying their marriage laws.
 
 Even the opposition to same-sex marriage effectively concedes that they are not allowed to do so. The push for a Constitutional amendment shows that.
